Hoffman Retaliates
Concerning the supposed violations of the rushing agreement,
IFB President, Pete Hoffman was
quoted as saying, "The interpretation of the agremeent seems to
depend on the previous year's results. Because of the very nature
of the competitive system, it is
difficult for the fraternities to determine what the results might
have been if the rates had been
read differently. Always hoping
for improvement, the fraternities
seem to rebound from each lax
year to one of stringent enforcement."
The interfraternity board will
devote a part of its regular meeting this Friday to consider the
conditions of the fraternities with
special attention to be given to
prospective changes in the rushing
rules, Hoffman added.

Bulletin Board
BY FRANK MURAL
The Registrar's Office reminds
all campus organizations and students that any notices to be posted
are first to be cleared with the
Office or with the specific department if a departmental board is to
be used. Permission may be obtained to post on other than the
official boards (trees, walls, etc.).
The Registrar warns that failure
to observe the standard University
posting procedures which include
clearance with the Registrar's Office and the use of masking tape
only on places other than the bulletin boards may soon cost everyone the posting privliege. Also, all
personal notices, such as advertisements of articles for sale, may
be posted only on the two boards
opposite the Post Office.

IRC Plans Lectures
On U. S.-European
Relations, Dec. 2
Four members of the Hopkins
faculty will discuss the popularity
—or the lack of it—of America
and Americans in Europe, at the
International
Relations
Club
meeting in Levering Hall on 'ruesday evening, December 2, at
8:30 p.m.
At this meeting, which will inaugurate the 1952-53 season of
the International Relations Club,
Dr. D. C. Allen, of the English
Department; Dr. N. Bryllion
Fagin, of the Drama Department;
Dr. H. Bentley Glass, of the Biology Department; and Dr. Edward
Williamson, of the Romance Language Department, will discuss:
"Americans: Are We Making
Friends in Europe", based on
their observations in England,
France, Italy, Western Germany,
and Austria in 1951 and 1952.

ney Rankin, editor-in-chief, announced.
The magazine, featuring articles
about the proposed engineering
building and "Symbolic Logic in
Time Switching Circuits," will sell
for $.25.
This issue inaugurates the Vector's seventh consecutive year of
publication, a record never equalled by any other Hopkins' student
magazine.
Proud'of this record, Rankin
said, "Past years have shown a
steady improvement in the Vector,
and we expect the future to be
even better."
Rankin added that the next issue might have a column for Alumni, reviewing news. This may be
done because one of the Vector's
functions is to keep engineering
alumni in touch with the school.
There will be three other issues
of the Vector this year, January
14, March 22nd, and May 18th.
At present the Vector has three
officials besides Rankin: Alec Jenkins, Business Manager; Gerard
Gilbert, feature editor; and Art
Thomas, campus editor.

As I See It
By V. V. LIBERABIT
A recent distribution, to the graduate members of one of our
departments, has been a memo concerning academic and intellectual
freedom. I have received a well-read copy of this,--and believe it
merits a greater audience. In view of recent pronouncements in the
closing days of the election campaign, more than a rebuttal, this
memo, which was written in 1944, raises to new heights a principle
whose validity had been challenged.
It is not my purpose to summarize this memo, but merely to
discuss the salient features in it. I am not so presumptuous as to
entertain the thought that I could make more lucid the thoughts so
clearly presented.

By ARTHUR WASKOW, Managing Editor

Shriver had been well-known
as an estate lawyer, and .had
caused controversy long before his
death at 72. He himself had been
involved in a will dispute in 1920,
when with his acquiescence he
was removed as trustee of. his
sister's share of money left by
their mother and grandfather.
In 1887 he had won an intercollegiate essay prize against 2500
rivals, and as a senior made Phi
Beta Kappa, having ranked first
in his class. After Hopkins graduate work for a year he took his
law degree at the University of
Maryland, and later was awarded
an honorary Master of Arts by
Loyola College.
He liked to travel, wrote several books, including The Law of
Wills of Personal Property in
Maryland, and helped found the
I Johns Hopkins University Club.

Tomorrow the 1952 Hopkins football team will ',make its
television debut while playing its finale against the GPIhn Terrors
of Western Maryland. Once again the Jays will be playing a role
that now has come quite familiar to them—that of the underdog.
Western Maryland has taken the last three games from the
Black and Blue, and the experts are picking them to repeat. Last
year the Terrors took the Mason-Dixon football title but could not
get going this season. Like the Jays, they dropped their first three
games,rebounded to take their fourth, but then, when things looked
like they were rolling well, they dropped their fifth game. In
their last two games however the Green wave seems to have come
up with the right formula, winning both.
For the Hopkins fan who wants to juggle comparative scores,
the Jays can't lose. Two weeks ago the Terrors slipped by Drexel
by a slim 6-0 score, but the .engineers were promptly dumped
again last week by mighty Swarthmore. Since the Jays beat
Swarthmore 33-9 with the sedond string in for over half the
game Hopkins is a shoo,in by 18 points. Further proof is given
by the Dickinson score. Last week the Jays thumped Dickinson
32-14 but the Terrors lost to Dickinson 7-6. This would make the
victory margin 19 points with the men from Homewood on the
long end of the count.
The Westminster supporters, on the other hand, are also
confident of'victory, and also point to the record to prove their
point. Western Maryland slapped a 19-7 defeat on HampdenSydney, but the Jays came a cropper at the hands of the Tigers,
losing- 28-25. Clearly this makes the Green Terrors a 'fifteen point
vietor.

Hoffman Retaliates
Concerning the supposed violations of the rushing agreement,
IFB President, Pete Hoffman was
quoted as saying, "The interpretation of the agremeent seems to
depend on the previous year's results. Because of the very nature
of the competitive system, it is
difficult for the fraternities to determine what the results might
have been if the rates had been
read differently. Always hoping
for improvement, the fraternities
seem to rebound from each lax
year to one of stringent enforcement."
The interfraternity board will
devote a part of its regular meeting this Friday to consider the
conditions of the fraternities with
special attention to be given to
prospective changes in the rushing
rules, Hoffman added.

faculty will discuss the popularity

Fagin, of the Drama Department;

Williamson, of the Romance Language Department, will discuss:
"Americans: Are We Making
Friends in Europe", based on
their observations in England,
France, Italy, Western Germany,
and Austria in 1951 and 1952.

discuss the salient features in it. I am not so presumptuous as to
entertain the thought that I could make more lucid the thoughts so
clearly presented.

Shriver had been well-known
as an estate lawyer, and .had
caused controversy long before his
death at 72. He himself had been
involved in a will dispute in 1920,
when with his acquiescence he
was removed as trustee of. his
sister's share of money left by
their mother and grandfather.
In 1887 he had won an intercollegiate essay prize against 2500
rivals, and as a senior made Phi
Beta Kappa, having ranked first
in his class. After Hopkins graduate work for a year he took his
law degree at the University of
Maryland, and later was awarded
an honorary Master of Arts by
Loyola College.
He liked to travel, wrote several books, including The Law of
Wills of Personal Property in
Maryland, and helped found the
I Johns Hopkins University Club.

Tomorrow the 1952 Hopkins football team will ',make its
television debut while playing its finale against the GPIhn Terrors
of Western Maryland. Once again the Jays will be playing a role
that now has come quite familiar to them—that of the underdog.
Western Maryland has taken the last three games from the
Black and Blue, and the experts are picking them to repeat. Last
year the Terrors took the Mason-Dixon football title but could not
get going this season. Like the Jays, they dropped their first three
games,rebounded to take their fourth, but then, when things looked
like they were rolling well, they dropped their fifth game. In
their last two games however the Green wave seems to have come
up with the right formula, winning both.
For the Hopkins fan who wants to juggle comparative scores,
the Jays can't lose. Two weeks ago the Terrors slipped by Drexel
by a slim 6-0 score, but the .engineers were promptly dumped
again last week by mighty Swarthmore. Since the Jays beat
Swarthmore 33-9 with the sedond string in for over half the
game Hopkins is a shoo,in by 18 points. Further proof is given
by the Dickinson score. Last week the Jays thumped Dickinson
32-14 but the Terrors lost to Dickinson 7-6. This would make the
victory margin 19 points with the men from Homewood on the
long end of the count.
The Westminster supporters, on the other hand, are also
confident of'victory, and also point to the record to prove their
point. Western Maryland slapped a 19-7 defeat on HampdenSydney, but the Jays came a cropper at the hands of the Tigers,
losing- 28-25. Clearly this makes the Green Terrors a 'fifteen point
vietor.
